text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Tom Kha gai that's right this
spicy soup is the perfect use for
leftover Thanksgiving turkey for like a
million reasons but let me give you just
three off the top of my head first it's
very fast and easy secondly it's very
nutritious with incredible restorative
powers I mean this stuff's like
borderline medicine and third most
important it's the complete polar
opposite of what you had for your
Thanksgiving meal so for me this is the
perfect recipe to use up those last
scraps of turkey and this is how you do
it
so of course besides the leftover turkey
meat we're going to need some kind of
stock or broth and of course you could
just use a carton of chicken broth but
I'm guessing you got some turkey bones
around so you could just make your own
like I did and if you're not sure how to
do that go watch our chicken stock video
and in a short 10 hours later I had a
beautiful beautiful turkey stock which I
strained so that's not we're going to
have to do before you start this recipe
or like I said you could just use carton
broth but either way we're going to
transfer about six cups of that into my
pot and we're going to place that on
medium high heat and bring it up to a
simmer and while we're waiting for that
to happen let's go ahead and prep the
first wave of the ingredients so we're
going to start with one of the signature
flavors of this soup lemongrass so I'm
going to trim off the bottom and if you
never work with this stuff before it's
very tough and woody and what we want to
do first is give it a little pounding
with the back of the knife and
apparently that helps release a lot of
the flavor or so I've been told
and once we've given that a little beat
down we're simply going to slice it up
like this and don't worry about
precision knife skills this is all going
to get strained out so we're gonna slice
up some lemongrass and then we're also
going to slice up some ginger root which
by the way is not the authentic
ingredient in this they just simply
called galanga root which is similar but
not exactly the same and I'll talk about
that in the blog but anyway we're going
to slice up some ginger root which
brings us to the next aromatic
ingredient some lime leaves except I
don't have lime leaves but I do have a
Meyer lemon tree and the smaller younger
leaves off that will work but if you can
find the lime leaves I think they're
called kaffir lime leaves those are what
you really want to use so we're going to
slice up a little bit of lemon or lime
leaf and then last but not least a
little bit of cilantro stem we're going
to use the leaf to finish the soup at
the end but I do like to include some of
the stems in the broth and at that point
we can go ahead and transfer that all
into our turkey stock along with some
dried chilies for heat now we're really
supposed
those little red dried Thai chilies but
these regular chili flakes will work and
we'll give that a stir and as soon as
that comes up to a simmer we will lower
our heat a little bit down to like
medium-low and we'll simmer this between
20 and 30 minutes okay we really want to
infuse that stock with all those
beautiful aromatic flavors so we'll let
that simmer while we prep the last of
the ingredients the first of which would
be some mushroom and you could pretty
much use anything you want in this but I
really like these little brown mushrooms
which in the stores I go to are usually
sold as clam shell mushrooms but I'm
pretty sure they have another name I
mean everything does and to prep these
all we need to do is slice off the
bottom which holds all those little
stems together and they will separate
and that's pretty much it okay so our
mushroom sets and then of course we're
going to need some leftover turkey
unattractive and completely unappetizing
at this point but that's okay we're
going to slice this and cube it up and
bring it back to life and then some one
of the secrets here is you want to cube
this kind of small this stuff's not
going to cook in the soup that long so
we want a small to absorb the flavors
Plus and I know this would never happen
to any of you because you watch the
channel but just for the sake of
argument let's say your turkey was a
little dry if you cut this up kind of
small at this point no one will be able
to tell us dry in the soup okay so our
mushrooms in our turkey are ready and
we'll head back over to the stove we're
by now my stock has simmered for about
25 minutes and before we add the
mushrooms in the turkey in I'm gonna do
one optional but extremely extremely
required step I'm gonna take one of
these skimmer strainers and remove all
those ingredients from the broth they've
served their purpose and for me just get
in the way when you're trying to eat
this in the restaurants they don't care
they figure you can just eat around it
which is fine but I think it's much
nicer and user friendly if you strain it
out so that's what I'm doing here but
that's up to you you are the whatever
the word and tie for bosses of your soup
and at this point whether you strain it
or not we're going to go ahead and add
in our mushrooms and our turkey we're
also going to add in a little bit of
sugar you can just use white sugar I'm
going to use a palm sugar because I have
it and I believe that's what they use
over there but we do need a little bit
of sweetness to balance the lime juice
that's coming later we're also at this
point could add some fish sauce so a
couple tablespoons of that we will
adjust that later of course as we will
all these flavors and we'll give that a
stir and then what we want to do is let
that simmer for about 10-15 minutes so
those mushrooms cook a little bit and
that turkey absorbs the flavors of the
broth and while we're waiting we can get
one of the last major and most important
ingredients some fresh lime juice and I
usually don't show steps like squeezing
lime juice but this was just so
beautiful looking I thought it would
share so we're going to want to squeeze
some fresh lime juice and then we'll
head back over to the stove and once our
mushrooms in Turkey have simmered for
about 10 to 15 minutes we're ready for
the final steps so at this point we're
going to go ahead and dump in our
coconut milk
that's one can of regular coconut milk
I'm also going to throw in a little bit
of green onion and chopped cilantro and
we'll stir that in oh and by the way you
people that don't like cilantro don't
eat cilantro hate cilantro
you can substitute basil in this it's
fine that's not fine
but you can do it okay and then last but
not least our fresh lime juice and as
soon as this comes back to temperature
as soon as it's piping hot again you're
ready to serve except there is one last
thing I'm going to add in here and that
would be a little bit of chili oil now
we are going to use this to garnish the

are wimps and they wouldn't add any on
their own it also warms up that color a
little bit and of course you can buy
chili oil
but if you read the post I'm gonna
explain how to do yourself it's super
easy and once that was stirred in I was
ready to serve of course I'm going to
taste and adjust the seasonings though
you might want more lime or more sugar
or more heat other than maybe a little

was the only source of salt so check for
that maybe you want to add a little more
maybe you want to put a little pinch of
regular salt in up to you and once I
taste exactly how you want it let's go
ahead and ladle it up I like to serve
mine with a little extra cilantro and
lime on the side we'll drizzle some more
that chili oil over the top and that Tom
Kha gai is done and while the phrase
exploding with flavor is horribly
overused and almost always hyperbole in
this case it's actually true spicy sweet
sour salty savory you name it it's in
here just a fantastically delicious soup
and a great way to use up those

you won't be thinking I'm eating
